author: Cathy Toogood
title: The 5 best family days out from Manchester
text: Follow the links below to see the rest of our guide • The best family days out from Birmingham • The best family days out from Bristol • The best family days out from Newcastle • The best family days out from London Formby beach Just south of Southport, this National Trust beach is surrounded by pine forests. Try to spot rare red squirrels in the woodland, run up and down the impressive sand dunes, and play ball games on the miles of white sand. Dogs are welcome on the beach, too. 01704 878591; nationaltrust.org.uk/formby ; parking £5.60 per car or free to National Trust members. Formby is one of the best beaches in the north of England Photo: AP Aerial Extreme, Trafford Centre For a taste of the outdoors in the city, head for this high-rope experience just next to the Trafford Centre. The 38 obstacles, set to challenge all ages, include two zip wires, balance beams, rope bridges and scrambling nets and are as high as 27ft. Children from the age of six can swing, scream and scramble around the course.  0845 652 1736; aerialextreme.co.uk; adult £26, child £21, family of four £75.20. • The 20 best hidden beaches in the UK • How to survive a family trip to the zoo • Flying with children: 10 secrets to stress-free travel Monkey Forest Roam with Barbary macaque monkeys in 60 acres of woodland, just an hour’s drive south of Manchester, in Trentham. Children can’t help being excited when they hear a rustle in the trees above or see one of the 140 resident monkeys bounding down a path. If monkey spotting isn’t energetic enough, there are also two adventure playgrounds. 01782 659 845; monkey-forest.com ; adult £8, child (3-14) £6. • Manchester city guide Roam with Barbary macaque monkeys just an hour's drive south of Manchester Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Lyme Park On the edge of the Peak District (about 40 minutes south east of Manchester in Disley), this large National Trust estate played the role of Pemberley in the 1995 BBC adaptation of Pride and Prejudice. Spot deer while following this summer’s “Xplorer” family orienteering trails or race around on a Get Sporty taster day. There is a Gruffalo trail for young children, muddy den-building days and under-12s will love the Crow Wood play park. 01663 762023; nationaltrust.org.uk/lyme-park ; adult £9.90, child £5; parking £7 per car. • 50 great days out in the UK • Holiday complaints: what to do when things go wrong • How to survive a long car journey with children Clayton Vale mountain bike trails Just a couple of miles north east of Manchester city centre, you can get muddy as a family on the National Cycling centre’s mountain bike trails. Along the Medlock river, there is a gentle “Easy Rider” route for first-timers, but there is plenty for more experienced thrill-seekers. Refuel at the on-site Velopark Café afterwards.  0161 223 2244; nationalcyclingcentre.com . Follow @telegraphtravel
